I'm sitting in a room containing oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide molecules. The air in the room has a pressure = approximately 760 KPa and a temperature near 25 C. No gas molecule in the room has the properties of temperature and pressure.

My human brain is causing me to type this message, but no single neuron in my brain is capable of getting me to type this message. Why does Nagel have such a problem with how the brain functions to produce mental phenomena; yet, I assume he readily accepts the fact the kinetic theory of gases adequately explains temperature and pressure as emergent properties?

I read your book this summer, and enjoyed it. This short form of the argument hinges on the nature of explanation. How do we describe the experience of our subjective, first person reality? How does a 'third person' explanation become a 'first person' experience? What would it mean for a description to be adequate to subjective reality?

You believes that the scientific worldview, as traditionally understood, cannot make this jump. You call for an "expanded form of understanding that includes the mental but that is still scientific." After talking about the limits of the traditional scientific worldview, it is unclear why you want to hang onto this term. In the face of scientific reductionism you seems to want a scientific maximalism, where just the right extra bit could be added to the scientific paradigm to capture subjective consciousness.

This approach seems similar to the zombie universe example: imagine an atom by atom copy of our universe, but one in which the people were zombies rather than conscious beings. What, exactly, is missing between the two universes? Now the thought exercise is: imagine a version of science that is an exact copy of our existing science, but one that is able to fully describe the experience of being conscious. What, exactly, has been added to science?

I quit philosophy when I fell in love with pictures. I realized that text would never be the same as an image no matter how much extra I wrote.

Now I'm in the NYU Art Department.

number of things... legal daycare businesses pay business taxes and insurance premiums (premiums are pretty cheap overall, surprisingly, but vary depending on coverage the operator is buying). Second, one employee in a daycare center, even as many don't have health insurance, cost a legitimate employer rather more than what they pay the employee. If the employee costs the employer $16/hr. to pay for (her wage + employer expenses paid to the gov't), at 40 hrs/wk x 4 wks. x 12 mos. = $30,720. Say the operator has 4 employees, all costing $30,720/yr.; ttl cost for employees is $122,880.

So, at any one time, the center has 20 kids in it. If the parent(s) are charged $20,000/yr. ttl for each kid, gross revenue for the center is $400,000. 400-122 leaves $278k. Probably, 20 kids means there's a location: a building of some kind. Rent will vary from location to location, but 20 kids probably need about 1500 sq ft at least, right? Say then it costs in rent or mortgage about $1,100/mo. So now it's another $13,200 on top of it for expenses. Down to $264k. Add monthly charges like electricity and water: possibly another $15,000+ total. So now we have $250k left and we haven't added the costs of food: lunches and snacks parents expect the center to provide. Other costs? Possibly, like do you want at least half the child minders to be EMS-certified as EMT-Basics, for example? That drives their wages up, then. Then there's business taxes.

So, you get the idea, I hope.

Why is it that bikes are occasionally dismissed because they don't serve all people -- the elderly, young children, the handicapped - but that cars never are? No young child can drive a car. Many elderly can not longer drive. And plenty of people people with specific disabilities can not drive either.

Yet think of all the able-bodied, physically capable people who drive even just a short distance. If these people chose to bike on safe streets with bike lanes, it would make it far easier for the people who absolutely must drive to do so. The entire point is that there is no one-size-fits-all solution to our transportation problems. I bike when it makes sense, drive when I have to get someplace a bike can not, and otherwise take the subway or bus. Only the media creates this myth of "special interest groups" that only represent the needs of the few.

As for the weather, Citi Bike achieved over 35,000 trips on one of the hottest days of the year this summer. Some of the best cycling cities in the world, such as Amsterdam and Copenhagen, have terrible weather with long periods of rain, snow, and cold temperatures. Safety and convenience, not weather, is the real reason people choose one mode of transportation over the other.

I am all for bikes, sure, but bike fans seem to forget the many (young children, the elderly, the handicapped, etc.) who will not be served by bikes. Also, what about bad weather days - snow, rain, wind, very hot days? On those days the overall interest in bikes will decline.

So often one group (Manhattan residents, bikers, etc.) speak as if they represent the total NYC population. If only these citizens would address the needs of the many, or at least reference them, it would be more acceptable and seem less like competing special interest groups.

Jerry, the short answer is that EITHER the marginal efficiency of capital along its schedule has gone up in the long--run, but not in the short-run, OR the domestic leveraged carry-trade into bonds fueled by QE has come to an end with rumors of QE taper.*

According to Keynes, the marginal efficiency of capital is negatively affected more by input prices in the short-run and more by competition in the long-run. If you aggregate the expected yield from various investments over different time intervals you get the schedule of the marginal efficiency of capital. In a liquidity trap, the short-term real rate is too high to induce full employment-restoring investments except those with a very short time horizon, where competition is not an issue. The long-term rate is basically boot-strapped from the short-term rate and is too high for the marginal efficiency to be positive considering competition in the long-run.

The monetary authority can only induce long-term investments, if it can credibly lower the long-run rate such that it falls below the expected long-run aggregate marginal efficiency of capital. In practical terms, this means the Fed quantitatively swaps long-range debt for short-term liquidity and the banks, in turn, swap liquidity for long-term assets including bonds and loans. The secondary market follows suit....

...unless of course, the secondary market is significantly leveraged and is unwinding in a run for the exit.

*Yes, that be the latter most likely
